column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=1 .
#Text=Introduction
#Text=Transparent conductive oxides ( TCOs ) play an important role as contact materials in solar cells .

#Text=The front contacts simultaneously fulfill numerous requirements : high transparency , high conductivity , and in some cases exhibit a surface texture that facilitates a good optical performance of the solar cell .
#Text=Many publications have already addressed the importance of balancing the transparency to reduce absorption losses and the electrical properties of TCO films in thin-film solar cells .
#Text=An even larger number of publications address the importance of rough interfaces for optical performance .
#Text=While most studies focus on silicon thin film solar cells , light management has been studied in copper indium gallium selenide ( CIGS ) and metal halide perovskite technology as well .
#Text=The majority of these publications refer to the necessity of good light-trapping in the device to foster the absorption of the otherwise weakly absorbed red portion of the solar spectrum .
#Text=Ideally , the light is trapped completely within the device due to total internal reflection or in other words : it is coupled to waveguide modes .
#Text=The pathway enhancement is of special importance for the wavelength range that faces a low absorption coefficient ( in silicon : 700 nm â€“ 1100 nm ) .
#Text=Numerous optical models have been designed to describe the scattering effects at the front ZnO : Al/Si interface .

#Text=While the haze , which represents scattering of the rough interface transmitted or reflected into air , is easily measured , scattering of that interface towards the subsequent silicon layer with a higher refractive index reduces the scattering angle by refraction .
#Text=Recent studies also addressed the importance of the back contact texture rather than the front contact texture .
#Text=In a simple picture , the light passes the front contact interface with small scattering angles , while a significant scattering takes place at the rough reflector .
#Text=However , the coupling to waveguide modes is a complicated interplay between front and back surface texture .
#Text=Hence , the back contact topography is of great importance for the light-trapping ability of the solar cell .
#Text=Before light can be trapped it has to enter the absorber layer first .
#Text=This is facilitated by an improvement of the light-coupling into the device and is very important for technologies using absorbers with high refractive index like silicon .
#Text=Some groups applied special anti-reflection coatings with intermediate refractive index between the TCO and the silicon .
#Text=In addition , rough interfaces are well known to reduce reflection losses .
#Text=An effective refractive index grading at rough interfaces is given once the two materials , e. g. , Si and TCO , mesh in the sub-wavelength length scale .
#Text=The incoming light experiences a gradual change from the pure refractive index of ZnO to the one of Si .
#Text=The extent of the improvement and the wavelengths that benefit most depend strongly on the texture properties .
#Text=Small features are required for good light-coupling , while larger features more effectively scatter light .
#Text=Thus , double textures have been developed including chemical deposition of ZnO or SnO2 , etched TCOs , a combination of those , and textured substrates .
#Text=A theoretical approach to double textured gratings was derived by Lee et al. .
#Text=Some papers mention the anti-reflection effect .
#Text=However , a detailed distinction of the effects of light scattering and its anti-reflection effect is lacking .
#Text=In this study , we present the analysis of the impact of different surface topographies on the aspects of light-coupling and light-trapping .

#Text=We utilize sputter-deposited aluminum-doped zinc oxide ( ZnO : Al ) and subsequent wet-chemical etching to demonstrate various kinds of textures that exhibit different abilities for light-trapping and light-coupling .
#Text=As a detector , we apply a silicon thin-film tandem solar cell consisting of hydrogenated amorphous and microcrystalline silicon as absorber .
#Text=Its structure is given in
#Text=Figure 1
#Text=a. Based on these findings a double texture is demonstrated , which combines the advantages of providing a light scattering with that of providing a light-coupling interface .
#Text=The double texture was realized by two-step etching of sputter deposited ZnO : Al .
#Text=Applied in a tandem solar cell it showed significant improvement in optical performance .
